= Process to service = In the '''Process to service''' section are listed the services offered. See [[TT-eBest_OF_Service_list-3|Service list]] in My catalogue section to change the service status. Click to open the process model list. Figure 195-Service list. Select the process model to assign, edit the recharge cost in percentage, and select the priority. The priority is a process model choice coefficient that indicate the process model the company prefer. Then click '''Save'''. Figure 196-Process model list. Click '''Set mappings''' to map the service parameter with the service parameters of the suppliers. Click a parameter name to map the parameter. Select an option among: Fix value, Map, Open. == Fix value == Select fix value to have always a fixed characteristic. In the example the server fixed value is always Apache. Click '''Save''' to store the information. Figure 197-Fix value parameter. == Map == Select Map, then click '''New mapping''' to associate the service parameters to the supplier service parameters. Click '''Save''' to store the mapping. Figure 198-Mapping parameters. == Open == Select Open, to associate the supplier parameter to the service parameters. If the service parameter is not defined the company parameter will coincide with the supplier parameter. Figure 199-Open parameter. "

= Pending actions = In the '''Pending actions''' section visualise the list of the accepted order line. (See [[TT-eBest_OF_Costumer_documents-3|Customer documents]]) Figure 201-Order line accepted. The company (once accepted an order line) has to plan the order line. When the company (Supplier in green) receives an order line from a customer has a '''supplier role'''. When the company plan the order line with its suppliers has the '''customer role''' (Customer in green in figure). The company plan the order line received sending the single activity inside an order line to his own suppliers. Figure 202-Plan an order line. The order line received from a customer and accepted by the supplier can be: # Planned manually, # Planned automatically. Click '''Manual''' to plan manually the order line, click '''Auto''' to plan automatically the order line. Figure 203-Plan a pending request. == Plan an order line manually (Company_Customer side) == Each activity is composed by one or more processes. In the process activity section assign each process to a supplier, select the '''Enabled''' check-box to include the activity to the plan. Click to assign a supplier to the process, click to save. Figure 204-Assign a supplier to a process activity. When all the processes are assigned to a supplier, click '''Generate plan''' to send the first process activity to the first supplier selected. If the supplier selected has accepted the process activity sent by the customer, the supplier have to schedule the process activity in the '''Internal scheduling''' section. See Reply to an order and [[TT-eBest_OF_Scheduler_menu-3|Scheduler menu]] for more details. Once a supplier accepted and schedule an order activity, the '''Duration''' in hours, the '''Start time''', the '''End time''' are sent to the customer. The customer in the '''Supplier documents''' section can visualise the order accepted by the supplier. See Supplier document. The second order line is sent automatically to the second supplier selected, and so on for each process activity. Figure 205-Process activity planned. When all the activities have been replied by the suppliers, click '''Planned''' and click '''Confirm plan''' to confirm the plan. In the customer documents the order status is in '''Planned''', click the order then click the order line and click '''Confirm''', '''Abort''' or '''Raise Exception'''. See [[TT-eBest_OF_Costumer_documents-3|Customer documents]] for more details. == Plan an order line automatically == Each activity is composed by one or more processes. When an order line is planned automatically the Planner selects for a process activity the fastest supplier among the available on the basis of the quotations exchange (quotations with a valid data). If there are not quotations available with a particular supplier the system sends automatically a quotation to the supplier for the process activity to plan. Once clicked '''Auto''' the order line become '''Manual'''. Once a supplier accepted and schedule an order activity, the '''Duration''' in hours, the '''Start time''', the '''End time''' are sent to the customer. The customer in the '''Supplier documents''' section can visualise the order accepted by the supplier. See [[TT-eBest_OF_Supplier_docunents-3|Supplier documents]]. The second order line is sent automatically to the second supplier selected, and so on for each process activity. In the customer documents the order status is in '''Planned''', click the order then click the order line and click '''Confirm''', '''Abort''' or '''Raise Exception'''. See [[TT-eBest_OF_Costumer_documents-3|Customer documents]] for more details. == Planner exception == When the supplier raises an exception on a planned order, the supplier node will notify automatically the changes to the planner. When a supplier raises an exception has to re-schedule the order and confirm the new order scheduled. When the supplier confirms the new scheduling, the changes are transmitted, the planner will verify if the changes modify other changes in cascade. If the new end date computed by the supplier delays the subsequent order start date of the company the order status changes in '''Exception'''. See the order line details in [[TT-eBest_OF_Costumer_documents-3|Customer documents]]. The order must be re-scheduled with the new start date. If the new end date computed by the supplier doesn’t delay the subsequent order start date of the company, the exception raises by the supplier doesn’t change the subsequent order of the company. = Current plan = In the current plan section are listed the order already planned. Click '''View''' to show the planned orders. Figure 206- Current plan. "

=Public Interface=  When accessing the framework the Collaboration website is shown. The website provides publicly available information about the ecosystem.  ==WEBSITE CONTENT PRESENTATION== [[Image:ebest_public_interface.jpg|middle|thumb|The layout of the Collaboration website is depicted on the following image]] The content of the website is managed inside the Collaboration portal. The hierarchy of publicly available information is assembled by the ecosystem administrators, typically the association responsible for organizing the joint activities of the ecosystem. Content placed at the hierarchy items can be edited by all ecosystem members.  The header and the footer (logos, Ecosystem name and contact information) is permanent on all website pages. The left column contains the navigational menu representing the hierarchy, the content of each page is displayed on the right column.  The sample implementation website opens with an introduction homepage of the eBEST Collaboration framework. The left side menu collects news and short descriptions (OKISZ - Hungarian partner), eBEST Collaboration framework and sample services (Tendering and Event Organization).

=Ecosystem interface=  After the login process the Collaboration Portal is shown. The portal provides different functions for the registered ecosystem users. Under the Ecosystem interface the basic functions are available from the Dashboard or from the main menu.  In this section the basic functions of eBEST Collaboration framework Portal available for all ecosystem members is described. The functions can be accessed from the main menu. The structure of the menu is the following: * Dashboard * Menu ** News ** ToDo ** Notices ** Content management ** Companies ** OF Company search ** OF Company statistics ** Ecosystem shaping system companies * Processes ** {List of the imported processes} * Customization (Available only for ecosystem administrators) ** Website translation ** Website customization ** Hierarchy management * Settings * Account ** Personal settings ** Logout   [[Image:collab-dashboard.jpg]]

=Dashboard=  After the login process the start page of the eBEST Collaboration framework Portal, the Dashboard is displayed (see on the next illustration). The Dashboard collects all important up-to-date information on one single screen. It also includes shortcuts for accessing the main features of the Collaboration Portal. The Dashboard collects recent activities and information for the following functions: *News: The provision of the last news items harvested from the subscribed news sources. *My ToDo list: The latest ToDo items assigned to the given ecosystem member user *Latest notices:The list of the notification items generated by the different processes of the framework or received from other frameworks of the eBEST network. The envelope icons indicate the read/unread status of the notifications. *Processes: A list of the latest processes managed within the Collaboration Portal *Content management: The list of the contents managed within the portal, in order of the latest changes. Colour coding indicates the status of the given content. The heading of each block is a link to the given functional area. Clicking on any item of a given block leads to the presentation or administration of the entity  [[Image:ebest_collab_dashboard.jpg]]

=Menu=  General collaborative functions as well as the integration points with the overall eBEST architecture is available from the Menu:  *News *ToDo  *Notice *Content management *OF Company search *OF company *OF company statistics *Ecosystem Shaping companies  [[Image:collab-menu.jpg|700px]]  A detailed discussion of the functions is provided in the following chapter.

=Processes= Since processes should be tailored to the specific needs of the ecosystem, in this chapter we only present a manual for one of the many reference processes created within the eBEST project. During the eBEST project, five general processes were designed for the pilots and for reference purposes: * Tender process management * Marketing campain management * Event organizing workflow * Award management * Travel management workflow  [[Image:collab-processes.jpg|700px]]

=Customization=  ==Ecosystem basic setup== '''Administrators can set the following basic options for the framework:'''  *Ecosystem name:The Ecosystem name is displayed on all interfaces (Website and Portal) as well as all notifications. *Keywords and description:Providing keywords and a textual description for the ecosystem is mainly for search engine optimization purposes, it is embedded into the website for web crawlers. *Ecosystem admin e-mail:Administrators can set the central e-mail account for the ecosystem. *Language:The language setting defines the basic interface localization of the Portal. Currently the languages of the participating members of the eBEST project is available. *Company search URL:This URL is the address of the eBEST Operational Framework company search interface.  ==Appearance setup options== '''Administrators can set the following options regarding the appearance of the Collaboration Portal:''' *Logo:A JPEG or PNG file can be uploaded as a logo to represent the ecosystem. The image size is updated after the upload to fit the size requirements of the framework. It is advisable to upload a landscape orientation image. The logo is displayed on all pages of both the Website and the Portal, as well as the header of notification e-mails. *Link colour:A colour can be chosen that will be displayed at all not colour-coded linkable areas of the Portal, and the notification e-mails. *Footer text:The text provided here appears in the footer area of all interfaces.  [[Image:ebest_collab_customization2.jpg]]

=Settings=  Under the ‘Setting’ there is the RSS feed set up where the subscription can be managed.  Creating a new subscription  Insert a proper RSS feed url (e.g. http://www.peppol.eu/News/news/RSS) to enable automatic feed element import/update. Please note that it is not a personal feed list, imported feed elements will appear to all Collaboration Framework users.  [[Image:ebest_collab_subc.jpg]]   ==Creating a new subscription == The “Add a subscription” button leads to a page where a new feed source can be entered or pasted. The portal accepts semantically validated feed sources. The feed sources are harvested every day, and feed items are stored in the local database of the portal. Please note that it is not a personal feed list, imported feed elements will appear to all Collaboration Framework users. [[Image:ebest_collab_subc2.jpg]]

=Account= Under the Account menu item basic information is displayed about the logged in ecosystem member. ==Personal settings== The personal settings functionality lets the user modify basic settings of his/her account. This is the area where the interface language and localisation settings can be set. The Portal has a default configuration for the ecosystem’s localization, but the user can alter the language to his/her own. The notification settings is also available here. A list of possible notification events are displayed, the user is free to set which cases the notifications need to be sent via e-mail. [[Image:ebest_collab_notification.jpg]]  The automatically generated e-mail notifications follow a common template. A ToDo notification is displayed by example: [[Image:ebest_collab_notification2.jpg]]  An additional option for using text based or html messages are also available. In case the user mainly reads messages from mobile devices, it is advised to turn the html e-mail option off. Once a user receives an account for the portal, it is advisable to verify the personal settings.    ==Log out== The Log out button closes the user session and forwards the user to the login screen. Please note that the logout from the Collaboration Portal does not result to close the session of the other frameworks of the eBEST architecture.

=Tender Process= [[Image:ebest-tender.jpg|thumb|350px]] The Tender process serves as a unified workflow for companies to participate in international or domestic tenders as consortium members.
The workflow covers the whole process from finding a tender, building a consortium, assembling tender material and submitting it to the requesting authorities.
Under the ‘Tender process’ you can find a list of created processes already being managed by the portal. Opening a process leads to the management interface with the given status. ==Illustrations== Many graphical illustrations help and navigate you on the portal. If you click on a call for tender you can see on the middle of the page the Status of the selected Request for Proposal (RFP). Under this measuring icon you can see the submission deadline of the RFP and details of the Tender Manager. [[Image:ebest-status.jpg|350px]] ==Creating a Tender== On the following figure you can see the process steps of a Tender process. During the process each step has a different management interface which should be filled out with the attributes of the given process step. Parallel steps within a process may exist, just like in the first part of the Tender process. Every participating member may update the process step information, but only the person responsible for the process can change the phase (proceed or revert the process to a previous state) of the process.
[[Image:ebest-tender2.jpg|center]] *The '''first process step''' is to initiate the process, to find a call for tender. After then you can fill out the ‘Create Tender’ form with the necessary information e.g.: Requesting Party – Organization or Authority announcing the Call for Tender -, Subject, Submission date – using calendar function- and Tender manager – the responsible for the tendering process-.
After saving the first milestone of the process called ‘the purchase RFP’ (Request for Proposal) is available on the page. Here you can give the RFP details e.g.: RFP web address, RFP documentation list, RFP price and date of announcement. If you have filled out the form you need to save it with the ‘Save’ button. If you are sure that you want to continue the process choose the ‘Proceed’ button. After saving, if you want to change on the form you should use the ‘edit’ button on the top of the form.
[[Image:ebest-tender3.jpg|center]] *The '''second step is the ‘Interpretation’ '''. Here you can define tasks and give descriptions from them. A simple help text coming from the ontology definition is displayed on the top right corner of every label of an attribute: [[Image:ebest_collab_tender4.jpg|center]] *The '''third step''' is the consortium member selection. Here you can invite a partner or partners for the proposal. If you click on the ‘Invite members’ button, the consortium manager will appear. Under this function you can select one of the registered companies and one of its representatives. In the message box you can give detailed information about the request. [[Image:ebest_collab_tender5.jpg|center]] Invitations are sent out to the companies, where they can accept the proposal or decline from cooperation. *The '''fourth step''' is the Task distribution process. Here process members can define and agree upon the Premises. *The '''fifth step''' is the Consortium team finalization. Here can the members upload the final documentation and agreements. *The '''sixth step''' is the Technical Proposal list. *The '''seventh step''' consists of four parallel subtasks, which can be managed paralelly. ** The first sbtask is the Project organization where you can define the Responsibilities, Project sponsor, Quality assessment, Technical support list. ** The second subtask is the ’Business Cases’. Here the consortium provides the following information: Quotation price, Unit price and Options price and attach files: Financial envelope and Performance bond. ** The third one is the ‘Eligibility’ subtask. Under this step Reference list, CV of Specialists and Balance sheet list can be provided. ** The fourth subtask is the Project Plan, where the final Project plan document is managed. *The '''eighth step'''is the ‘Tender Review’. Under this step you can create and upload review materials and attach a content to be published about the process on the ecosystem website. Finally you can complete the whole process.

=Event organization= Under the ‘Event organization’ there are created processes by other ecosystem member. If you choose one of these events you can read more about the selected item e.g.: description, its status and participants, deadlines and the next steps. If one of created tenders is suitable for your company you can send request for event organizer with your interest. Many graphical illustrations help and navigate you on the website. If you click one of events you can see on the left side of the page the whole process and Status of the selected event. Under this measuring icon you can see the submission deadline of event and the name of Event organizer. ==Creating an Event== On the following figure you can see the steps of an Event organization. During the process each step has different form which should be filled out with information and after then can be continued the process (but there are 2 steps(Content and Logistic preparation) which can be done parallel these exceptions are indicated). Click to the ‘Create Event organization’ button.
*The '''first step''' is to know the event itself. After then you can fill out the ‘Create Event organization’ form with the necessary information e.g.: Event name – Event organizer – Target date. *The '''second step''' is the ‘Event planning’. You need to collect the event objectives and upload on the website. If you filled out the form you can save it with using the ‘Save’ button. If you are sure not to continue the process choose the ‘Cancel Process’ button. *The '''third step''' is a parallel process. In this case you can choose from Content preparation or the Logistic preparation depending on which do you prefer fill out at first. Here you can add and upload ‘Logistics’ element and ‘Content’. After saving click to the ‘Communication’ button. *The''' fifth step''' is the ‘Registration’ process. During this step should be created and uploaded a registration form and registered members. After saving click to the ‘Actual Event’ button. *The '''sixth step''' is the Actual Event. During this step ’Event Preparation Documents’ should be created and uploaded. After saving the changes click to the ‘After event activities’ button. *The''' seventh step''' is the ‘After event activities’. During this step Dissemination Plan, Publications and name of Participants should be created and uploaded. If you are ready with the content and uploadings but you do not want to finish the whole event process you should click to the ’Save’ button. If you finished the whole process you can close it with using the ‘Finish process’ button.
[[Image:ebest-event.jpg|center]]

=Portal translation=  The inclusion of the translational module is necessary for two purposes: Since processes can be freely defined and automatically imported to the framework, new terms emerge. These terms are provided in the lingua franca (English), and thus it might be necessary to translate them to the other languages. It is also possible, to configure the Collaboration framework for the handling of new languages. In this case the translation module provide the means to translate the complete interface to the new language. The translation interface provides a simple label – value editing option for all terms to be translated. A Filter for searching for a specific term is also available: [[Image:ebest_collab_portal_translation.jpg]]

One can freely add, edit or delete menu items at any hierarchy levels: main menu elements are listed under the Public Website menu container, while submenu elements are listed under their parent main menu items and so on. [[Image:ebest_collab_hierarchyMan.jpg]]

=Strategy Management=  Strategic management is a field that deals with the major intended and emergent initiatives taken by general managers on behalf of owners, involving utilization of resources, to enhance the performance of ﬁrms in their external environments.  [[Image:strategy.jpg]]  ==References== http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Strategic_management http://assignmenthelpexperts.blogspot.com/2011/03/what-is-resource-based-view-in.html

=Strategic analysis=  Strategic analysis is one of the key elements of strategic management. Strategic analysis helps to understand the company´s strategic position. It is important to analyse environmental changes and find out how they can affect you and your employees. Strategic analysis aims to create a view of the key factors which can have an impact on the present and future performance of your company. If strategic analysis is carried out in a correct manner then it will help you choose the right strategy.  The key factors are: company environment, resources of the company and expectations of different stakeholders (i.e. objectives within the cultural and political framework).  ==References==  Strategy‐Train (Small Enterprise Strategic Development Training) is co-funded by the European Commission. http://www.strategy-train.eu/index.php?id=24

=Strategic goals=  Strategic goals are statements of what the company management wishes to achieve over the period of the strategy. Strategy implementation is a process involving all team members within the company and team work is exceptionally important. The manager has to have good communication and managerial skills, as well as financial expertise to be able to network among the team members, suppliers, subcontractors and customers on a day-to-day basis. At the same time he has to follow the strategic goals and meet deadlines and budget restrictions as well as considering the motivation, skills and competence of the whole team. Team members should know their responsibilities, their commitment is of great importance.   ==References==  Strategy‐Train (Small Enterprise Strategic Development Training) is co-funded by the European Commission. http://www.strategy-train.eu/index.php?id=24

=Strategy Implementation =  The final step, strategy implementation is defined as the way in which you will translate your strategy into actions. Strategic implementation requires careful planning and proper deployment of your company´s resources, careful handling of possible changes in your organisation structure and effective change management. Implementation of your strategy can take place in several stages, thereby the main three stages are: (a) Planning and allocating resources, (b) Organizational structure and design, (c) Managing strategic change.  ==References==  Strategy‐Train (Small Enterprise Strategic Development Training) is co-funded by the European Commission. http://www.strategy-train.eu/index.php?id=24

=SWOT analysis=  The following five steps will help you to use SWOT analysis in your company and to decide on the best course of action based on the results. (Lombriser & Abplanap 2005). The table below provides an outline of how to implement strategies when considering your strengths, weaknesses, opportunities and threats. Key rules for SWOT analysis: Identification of decisive success factors: It is very helpful for the strengths-weaknesses analysis to identify decisive success factors. This is an important task, but normally you know them and you can easily sketch them.   [[Image:swot.jpg|frame|thumb|180px]] *1)Determination of strengths and weaknesses:  In a strengths-weaknesses analysis the competitive position of your company in relation to the strongest competitor(s) is identified. In considering comparable factors you should only take into account those points that are really comparable (is such data really available?). Consider that all identified strengths and weaknesses are relative. As they are relative they gain informative value only through benchmarking (see previous subsection).  *2) Determination of opportunities and risks:  This part of the SWOT analysis discovers opportunities and threats that result from new trends and changes in your environment. Factors that do not influence your company directly are considered to be external factors in the SWOT analysis. E.g. high customer loyalty can be classified as an internal strength, but can turn into a threat, if traditional customer ties become less important.  *3)Processing of the questionnaire and answering of key questions:  In this step you should answer questions that mostly relate to the sector in which you are engaged.  *4) Deduction of strategic conclusions:  If you can anticipate and react to present and future changes, you have achieved one of the major goals of a SWOT analysis.  ==References==  Strategy‐Train (Small Enterprise Strategic Development Training) is co-funded by the European Commission. http://www.strategy-train.eu/index.php?id=24

=Benchmarking=  Benchmarking is the measurement of the quality of a firm's policies, products, programs, strategies, etc., and their comparison with standard measurements, or similar measurements of the best-in-class firms. The results determine improvements needed, identify the way other firms achieve their high performance levels, and using this information help to improve the company's performance.  ==References==  Strategy‐Train (Small Enterprise Strategic Development Training) is co-funded by the European Commission. http://www.strategy-train.eu/index.php?id=24

=Competitive advantage=  A firm is said to have a competitive advantage over its competitors, when maintaining returns that surpass the average in its industry. This advantage is derived from the characteristics of a product that make it superior to competitive products.   ==References==  Strategy‐Train (Small Enterprise Strategic Development Training) is co-funded by the European Commission. http://www.strategy-train.eu/index.php?id=24

=Marketing Mix=  A \Marketing Mix\" is a planned mix of the controllable elements of a product's marketing plan commonly termed as 4P's: product, price, place, and promotion. These elements are adjusted until a right combination is found that serves the needs of the product's customers while generating optimal income. Sometimes the first P (Product) is substituted by 'presentation'.  ==References==  Strategy‐Train (Small Enterprise Strategic Development Training) is co-funded by the European Commission. http://www.strategy-train.eu/index.php?id=24 "

=strategic choice=  A strategic choice is defined as the selection of the best possible course of action based on the evaluation of your available strategic options. Strategic choice is the second key element of strategic management. After undertaking strategic analysis you will be ready to make a strategic choice. Two main steps are identified: (a) Search for strategic fit or suitability of the strategy, (b) Selection of strategy. Thereby keep in mind that there is more than one strategy that you can choose. There is not a \right\" or a \"wrong\" choice, because choices always contain different threats and weaknesses.   ==References==  Strategy‐Train (Small Enterprise Strategic Development Training) is co-funded by the European Commission. http://www.strategy-train.eu/index.php?id=24 "

=Innovation=  Innovation can be: *Physical and technical infrastructure - machines, laboratories, research units, scientific equipment, experimental production, etc, *Labour/Human resources - specially trained scientific personnel, *Financial resources - financing research, *Information/Knowledge management.   ==References==  Strategy‐Train (Small Enterprise Strategic Development Training) is co-funded by the European Commission. http://www.strategy-train.eu/index.php?id=24

=Enterprise Vision and Mission=  [[Image:vision.jpg|frame|thumb|180px]]  A vision creates hope and mobilizes strengths of the employees and it creates positive energy. A vision facilitates the achievement of managerial objectives and supports the sustainability of your company.  A mission, on the other hand, helps you find your own direction in the business environment, while reflecting the values and beliefs of a group, it acts as a source of inspiration, as it is action orientated and, most importantly, realistic.  Vision and mission are tools which help you formulate your company policy, a factor which provides clear orientation to your company.  A \Marketing Mix\" is a planned mix of the controllable elements of a product's marketing plan commonly termed as 4P's: product, price, place, and promotion. These elements are adjusted until a right combination is found that serves the needs of the product's customers while generating optimal income. Sometimes the first P (Product) is substituted by 'presentation'.  ==References==  Strategy‐Train (Small Enterprise Strategic Development Training) is co-funded by the European Commission. http://www.strategy-train.eu/index.php?id=24     "

=General Company Policy=  The general policy of the company encompasses all company principles, which are shared with all stakeholders either in a written format or, sometimes, by word of mouth. Company principles dictate the behavioral guidelines within your company and the external environment. They express the vision, company values, norms and ideals, which make up your company culture. Through the establishment of a company policy the management tries to organize the company as a whole and establish solid regulations. Nonetheless, company policy should NOT be comprised of a rigid system of company guidelines, but it should convey a manner of thinking, according to which one should react when faced with various external and internal developments and which should also rate them in terms of their importance to the motivation and commitment of company staff. Once this has been done, then the orientation and content of company strategy should be decided upon.  ==References==  Strategy‐Train (Small Enterprise Strategic Development Training) is co-funded by the European Commission. http://www.strategy-train.eu/index.php?id=24

=Franchising=  Franchising is an arrangement where one party (the franchiser) grants another party (the franchisee) the right to use its trademark or trade-name as well as certain business systems and processes, to produce and market a good or service according to certain specifications. The franchisee usually pays a one-time franchise fee plus a percentage of sales revenue as royalty, and gains (1) immediate name recognition, (2) tried and tested products, (3) standard building design and décor, (4) detailed techniques in running and promoting the business, (5) training of employees, and (6) ongoing help in promoting and upgrading of the products. The franchiser gains rapid expansion of business and earnings at minimum capital outlay. (http://www.businessdictionary.com/definition/franchising.html)  ==References==  Strategy‐Train (Small Enterprise Strategic Development Training) is co-funded by the European Commission. http://www.strategy-train.eu/index.php?id=24

=Resources=  Firm-specific assets useful for creating a cost or differentiation advantage and that few competitors can acquire easily, as, for example, patents and trademarks, proprietary know-how, customer base, reputation of the firm and brand equity.  ==References==  Strategy‐Train (Small Enterprise Strategic Development Training) is co-funded by the European Commission. http://www.strategy-train.eu/index.php?id=24

=Functional rules/policies =  Functional rules/policies are a system of standardized processes, procedures and guidelines for workers and employees on how exactly they have to provide products and services. The steps to go through are formalized in guides which describe the processes.  ==References==  Strategy‐Train (Small Enterprise Strategic Development Training) is co-funded by the European Commission. http://www.strategy-train.eu/index.php?id=24

=Crises Management=  In general terms a crisis is the presence of threat and instability related to economic, political, military, ecological and other society problems. From a business point of view it can be organizational, caused by business relationships, derived from problems with technology and environment preservation. In order to be effective crisis management should be carefully planned and implemented in its 3 stages: 1. Programming crisis management (Planning), 2. Proactive crisis management (Acting) and 3. Post crises management (Analysing).

=3 C Model=   ==Groupware== About groupware: groupware can be defined as computer-based systems that support groups of people engaged in a common task by providing an interface to a shared environment. The goal of groupware is to assist groups in communication, collaboration, coordination How groupware works: server, client, replication  ==The model of 3C: communication, collaboration, coordination==  ===Communication=== It’s the transmission of knowledge. The communication model: Information source, transmitter, channel, receiver, destination and message (Shannon’s mathematical theory of communication).  Groupware communication: Sending and receiving a message or knowledge via different media sources. There are several ways to communicate: formal meetings, phone calls, presentations, electronic messaging, whiteboards, etc. Communication forms: one-to-one, one-to-many, many-to-many Communication with computer: *Electronic messaging: it can be asynchronous, for example newsletters. Different folders, filters and rules are useful for information management.  *Real time messaging: allows real time interact between participants, text based communication in real time, informal, simple and fast way of communication *Video conference: allows shared application or desktops during communication.   ===Collaboration=== Collaboration relies on shared space. Shared spaces are the collaborative tools that provide a context in which the whole of the relationship is greater than the sum of the individual participants’ expertise. Collaboration function is seen as shared space or shared tool, which allows group to work together. Group members have access to others information and knowledge.  It’s important to know who has done the work, who is dealing with those work right now, what other participants can see, etc.   ===Coordination=== Coordination is the integration of individual work towards shared objective (for example Workflow). Workflow: The automation of a business process, in whole or part during which documents, information or task are passed from one participant to another for action, according to a set of procedural rules. Coordination tools provide possibilities for managers to follow up group’s work and step into if needed.  Organization defines specific policies about how report is to be routed. Most real work involves a combination of highly structured processes and tasks where the process is fussy and the rules, routes and roles are dynamically defined as the work is being done. Coordination is supported by communication and collaboration. Everyone in the organization is responsible for finding information and scheduling their actions.   === 3C support solutions/applications ===  There are many groupware solutions in use some of them COTS, many open sources developments focus on one or more aspects of groupware.  As a practical application the eBEST Collaboration Framework is demonstrated. eBEST (Empowering Business Ecosystems of Small Service Enterprises to Face the Economic Crisis - FP7-SME-2008-2-243554) is co-funded by the European Commission. Project website: http://www.ebest.eu

==Basics of communication== Communication is from the Latin word \communis\", meaning to share. It requires a sender, a message and an intended recipient, although the receiver need not be present at the time of communication. Communicating parties need to  share an area of communicative commonality. The end of the process is when the receiver has understood the message of the sender. Feedback is crucial to effective communication between parties.  ==Human commmunication== Human  languages can be described as a system of symbols and the grammars by which the symbols are manipulated. The word \"language\" also refers to common properties of languages. Language learning normally occurs most intensively during human childhood. Most of  human languages use patterns of sound or gesture for symbols which enable communication with others around them. There are a variety of verbal and non-verbal means of communicating such as body language, eye contact, sign language, paralanguage, haptic communication, chronemics, and media such as pictures, graphics, sound, and writing.  ==Nonverbal communication== Nonverbal communication is the process of conveying meaning in the form of non-word messages. The majority of our communication is non verbal, also known as body language.  Some example for nonverbal communication: Gesture, body language, facial expressions, eye contact, object communication such as clothing, hairstyle, architecture and tone of voice as well as through an aggregate of the above.  ==Oral communication== Oral communication can also employ visual aids and non-verbal elements. Oral communication includes speeches, presentations, discussions. As a type of face-to-face communication, body language and voice tonality play a significant role, and may have a greater impact upon the listener than informational content. This type of communication also garners immediate feedback.  ==Written communication== Researchers divide the progression of written communication into three revolutionary stages called \"Information Communication Revolutions\".  *First stage:  written communication first emerged through the use of pictographs. The pictograms were made in stone, hence written communication was not yet mobile *Second stage:  writing began to appear on paper, papyrus, clay, wax, etc. Common alphabets were introduced and allowed for the uniformity of language across large distances. A leap in technology occurred when the Gutenberg printing-press was invented in the 15th century. *The third stage is characterized by the transfer of information through controlled waves and electronic signals.  ==Meta communication== Meta communication is communication that indicates how verbal information should be interpreted. Human communication involves kinesic and paralinguistic elements. These indicate how the verbal communication should be understood and interpreted. Meaning doesn’t depend on only literal verbal meaning, the same verbal message framed by different meta-communication can mean something entirely different.    ==Models of communication== Shannon’s mathematical theory of communication presents communication with 5 different parts: *information source *transmitter *channel *receiver *destination  ==Resources== #[http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Meta-communication MetaCommunication Wikipedia] #[http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Communication Communication Wikipedia] #[http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shannon%E2%80%93Weaver_model Shannon-Weaver model]    "

==Basics of collaboration== Collaboration is working together to achieve a goal. It is a recursive process where two or more people or organizations work together to realize shared goals by sharing information, learning and building consensus. Collaboration requires superiority. In certain teams that work collaboratively can obtain greater resources, recognition and reward when facing competition for finite resources. Collaboration is also present in opposing goals exhibiting the notion of adversarial collaboration, though this is not a common case for using the word. Structured methods of collaboration encourage introspection of behavior and communication. These methods specifically aim to increase the success of teams as they engage in collaborative problem solving. Forms, rubrics, charts and graphs are useful in these situations to objectively document  personal raits with the goal of improving performance in current and future projects.  ==Collaboration in technology== Due to the complexity of today's business environment, collaboration in technology encompasses a broad range of tools that enable groups of people to work together including social networking, instant messaging, team spaces, web sharing, audio conferencing, video, and telephony. Broadly defined, any technology that facilitates linking of two or more humans to work together can be considered a collaborative tool. Wikipedia, Blogs, even Twitter are collaborative tools. Many large companies are developing enterprise collaboration strategies and standardizing on a collaboration platform to allow their employees, customers and partners to intelligently connect and interact. Enterprise collaboration tools are centered around attaining collective intelligence and staff collaboration at the organization level, or with partners. These include features such as staff networking, expert recommendations, information sharing, expertise location, peer feedback, and real-time collaboration. It enables employees to enhance social awareness and their profiles and interactions Collaboration encompasses both asynchronous and synchronous methods of communication. Perhaps the most commonly associated form of synchronous collaboration is web conferencing (Cisco TelePresence, Microsoft Live Meeting, Lotus Sametime, Skype.)  ==Collaboration in business== Collaboration between team members allow better communication within the organization. It is a great way to generate wide variety of knowledge, coordinate ideas and improve business performance. The recent improvement in technology has provided the world with high speed internet, wireless connection, and web-based collaboration tools like blogs, and wikis, and has as such created a \mass collaboration.\" People from all over the world are efficiently able to communicate and share ideas through the internet, or even conferences, without any geographical barriers.  ==Effect of the Internet on Collaboration== *Low cost *Easy to use *Internet allows groups to easily form *Groups can cheaply communicate each other  ==Useful information and Resources== #[http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Collaborative_software Collaboration software] #[http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Collaboration Collaboration]      "

==Basics of coordination== Coordination is the act of coordinating, making different people or things work together for a goal or effect to fulfill desired goals in an organization. Coordination is a managerial function in which different activities of the business are properly adjusted and interlinked. Other perspective: Coordination is the integration of individual work towards shared objective. Workflow is an example for coordination. Coordination is supported by communication and collaboration.  ==Workflow== Workflow is the automation of a business process, in whole or part during which documents, information or tasks are passed from one participant to another for action, according to a set of procedural rules. It comprises a number of logical steps, which is known as activity. Automating the work  will increase efficiency. Workflow systems are based on forms, which are routed from person to person. This kind of workflow leaves each person in the group on their own, with no overview of the process. The domain of workflow has been to focus on highly structured business processes.  In this thesis groupware coordination function is seen as function, which helps to integrate and schedule individuals work to group objectives. Coordination tool provides possibilities for manager to follow up group’s work and step into if needed.  Most of the business activities are structured in nature. Organization defines policies about how to report is to be routed through an organization. Most real work involves a combination of highly structured processes and tasks where the process is fussy and the rules, routes and roles are dynamically defined as the work is being done.   ==Worfklow models== Workflow can based on messaging model. Workflow automation is typically associated with the automatic routing of documents. Route-based workflow automation generally uses messaging system to route documents to the next person, who must take an action. It’s a powerful workflow, because it matches the model of routing thesis: the document is acted upon and set to the next person for further action. There might be problems while document becomes unavailable to anyone other than the person in whose inbox it resides.  Shared database is another workflow model. Users consult a tracking database to check the status of specific documents. It has three advantages: # triggers can be used to start action without any specific user activity. # documents are available for others while the workflow proceeds. # model makes the management of workflow much easier.  The use of email may cause problems with version control and document management. Shared databases lacks the notification capability when needed. The coordinated use of messaging and shared databases in a fourth generation email system (attachments, rich text and hypertext links) resolves both of these problems. Messaging and shared databases are become the foundation for workflow automation systems. Those systems, which contain both functions, will be most successful.    ==Coordination tasks== Scheduling a meeting with a group is one of the group tasks, which might benefit from computer support. Finding free time in several personal schedules seems a task that can be done more efficiently with a groupware system. Creating documents (authoring) is a common task which computers help people to accomplish. Many documents, like reports, result from cooperation between two or more persons. Co-authoring systems are designed to support multiple users in their joint effort to create a document.  Complete coordination includes support for informal conversations that allow people to gather the information they need to get their jobs done, especially when these conversations happen in the context of a more structured process.  ==Useful information and resources== # [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Workflow Workflow] # [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coordination Coordination Wikipedia]

==Groupware communication== There are different communication functions, one of these is groupware communication. Groupware communication function is seen as sending and receiving information and knowledge in different forms via different media. Communication can occur between individuals or groups. It can also be synchronous or asynchronous. In communication, all basic elements of Shannon’s theory are needed. Groupware communication tools provide a channel between communicators.   ==Groupware systems in groupware communications== A groupware system manages groupware communications. A good groupware system has a balance between communication and conversation. You may be able to exchange information efficiently, and be able to chat informally as well. For instance, take an old groupware system -- the company: If a company is too informal, it takes too long to make a decision because of the amount of time it takes to reach a consensus between many parties. In a small company this can be ok, but in a large one it can take so long to resolve a crisis that the company can fail. The best companies keep a balance of formal communication and informal conversation. There is a reasonably efficient method of control over decision making, and enough chatting and conversations between individuals supplant the information gathering that affects decision making.  ==Groupware communication tasks== There are several task which should be managed by groupware system. Lotus Notes is a great example for groupware system, it provides the following tasks:  *Email *Bulletin board *Calendar *Forum *Workflow *Instant messaging *Videoconferencing systems  ==Useful information and Resources== #[http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Collaborative_software Wikipedia Groupware]

People communicate in many ways: formal meetings and presentations, memos, over the phone and in informal hallway meetings.   ==Electronic messaging== Electronic messaging is a powerful tool for notification and supports communication. Variables such as time, place and number of participants determine the most appropriate communication system in any given situation. Electronic messaging supports different-time and different-place information sharing. Electronic messaging is the store-and-forward transport of electronic objects among people. The design point of electronic messaging is the asynchronous transmission of messages from one place to another. Messages can contain different kinds of information and different form of messages for example text, pictures, files, etc.  Email is an effective medium for one-to-one and one-to-many forms of communication. Due to the lack of structure and volume of information being pushed, it appears that many-to-many communication quickly becomes unmanageable in this environment. Email is effective in supporting unstructured communication, but it fails with more complex level of interaction. Specially, many-to-many communication becomes quickly unmanageable. Email could be quite useful in certain situations, for  example manager may have need for occasional  interaction.  ==Real time communication== Real time computer conferencing allows group to interact synchronously physically dispersed. Computer conferencing can also be asynchronous like newsgroups. The most familiar examples of teleconferencing are conference calls and video conferencing. Workstation-based interfaces make the process more accessible. Desktop conferencing system uses the workstation as the conference interface and also runs applications shared by the participants.  ==Chat systems== Chat systems provide synchronous and text-based discussions between multiple users. Each sentences that is typed is immediately observable for the users, which facilitates rapid turn taking in discussions. Chat is very useful for simple and fast conversations. If specialists are available, needed information can be transferred quite fast. Other participants may also follow the conversation without necessity to participate.  ==Useful information and resources== #[http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Electronic_messaging Electronic messaging] #[http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Email Email communication] #[http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Instant_message Instant messaging]  # [http://notes.unl.edu/newnotes2/sametime.shtml Lotus Notes Sametime]

==Collaboration tools== Collaboration relies on shared spaces. Shared spaces are the collaborative tools that provide a context in which the whole of the relationship is greater than the sum of the individual participants’ expertise. In this thesis groupware collaboration function is seen as shared space or shared tool, which allows group to work together. Group members have an access to other member’s information and knowledge. Collaboration should not be examined alone without supporting communication. Awareness is important in communication. You need to know who has done what work, who is dealing with whose work now, what other participants can see and so on.   ==Shared databases== It differs from messaging systems. Shared databases house knowledge in one place. They make knowledge viewable through a common structure. Activities such as problem solving, brainstorming, identifying and locating data that has been created by others are all forms of collaboration. As in communication, one of the most important contributions of technology in collaboration is the elimination of the constraints of time and space. Shared databases provides a virtual common workspace with a group centered interface. It allows participants to share information, knowledge and ideas. Shared databases also support knowledge management. Where a shared view is provided, multiple forms of presentation are important, because people need to view information by date, by author, by document type, etc. End users should also be able to customize and modify information. A flexible, shared database at the core of a groupware system provides the platform on which a wide range of applications can be developed. This may vary from simple discussion databases to rich knowledge bases that support, for example, customer assistance systems and responses to questions. Shared databases and shared views are essential for common work.  ==Electronic meeting systems== Electronic meeting systems try to make group meetings more productive. Technology is designed to improve group effectiveness, efficiency, and satisfaction. Electronic meeting system can be used for example idea generation and group memory. One of the simple electronic meeting system is the electronic voting system. Anonymity may facilitate proposing bold ideas and giving honest opinions about ideas. Meeting support systems can facilitate viewing and manipulating electronic documents. Similarly, the systems may allow the generation of electronic documents.  ==Videoconferencing systems== Videoconferencing technologies allow people to collaborate across dispersed geographical areas. There is a system called media space, which uses integrated video, audio and allow individuals or groups to work together without leaving their offices.   Multimedia conferencing systems allow humans, who are geographically separated, to interact with different types of media over distance.  Computer conferencing systems allow users to send a message to a uniquely identified place in cyberspace devoted to discussion about a particular topic. Messages, which are sent with computer conferencing systems can be read by other users at a later time. Systems can also support different types of messages or documents and pictures.  Bulletin boards are used to provide much more coherent, common view of group interaction.   ==Shared whiteboards== Shared whiteboard systems are designed to support drawing sketches during discussions. Other people can refer or propose modifications to such drawings. Systems are useful specially when the participants are not in the same room. Some systems allow users to have a different view on the shared workspace, if they wish. Shared whiteboards allow multiple users to draw, type and gesture in the shared workspace simultaneously.  ==Group decision support systems== Problem solving work comprises such general-purpose tasks as brainstorming to generate ideas, structuring those ideas, and evaluating them. Group decision support systems provide computer-based facilities for the exploration of unstructured problems in a group setting. The goal of the group decision system is to improve the productivity of decision-making meetings, either by speeding up the decisionmaking process or by improving the quality of the resulting decisions.  ==Useful information and resources== #[http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Electronic_meeting_system Electronic meeting systems] #[http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Videoconferencing Videoconferencing]

==Electronic calendar== Calendaring software provides users an electronic version of calendar. Additionally, the software may provide an appointment book, address book, and/or contact list. Users are able to schedule events and automatically notify and remind group members.   Calendaring software can contain the following features: *calendar *address book *appointment attachment *appointment calendar *availability sharing *calendar publishing *Collaborative scheduling *Email *Group calendar *Printing *Web-based interface *Multi  viewing  ==Project management== It’s the discipline of planning, organizing, securing and managing resources to achieve specific goals. Project is a temporary endeavor with a defined beginning and end, typically to bring about beneficial change or added value.   The primary challenge of project management is to achieve all of the project goals.  Project management systems are for schedule, track, and chart the steps in a project as it is being completed. The following methods of project controlling can be applied: *investment analysis *cost-benefits analysis *simulation calculations *risk-profile analysis *milestone trend analysis *cost trend analysis *target/actual comparison  ==Knowledge management systems== It’s a subset of Enterprise content management software and contains a range of software that specializes in the way information is collected, stored and accessed. The concept of knowledge management is based on a range of practices used by an individual, a business, or a large corporation to identify, create, represent and redistribute information for a range of purposes. Knowledge Management Software in most cases provides a means for individuals, small groups or mid-sized businesses to innovate, build new knowledge in the group, and/or improve customer experience.   ==Online spreadsheets== It’s a spreadsheet document which is edited through a web-based application that allow multiple persons to edit. With Web 2.0  a new generation of online spreadsheets has emerged.  The best web based online spreadsheets have many of the features seen in desktop spreadsheet applications. Some of them have strong multi-user collaboration features. Some of them offer real time updates from remote sources such as stock prices and currency exchange rates. Online applications are now becoming known as \Cloud Apps\".    ==Other collaboration tools== *enterprise bookmarking -  collaborative bookmarking engine to tag, organize, share, and search enterprise data *online proofing - share, review, approve, and reject web proofs, artwork, photos, or videos between designers, customers, and clients. *prediction markets- let a group of people predict together the outcome of future events *social software systems - organize social relations of groups  ==Useful information and resources== #[http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Collaborative_software Collaborative software] #[http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Project_management Project management] #[http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Knowledge_management_software Knowledge management systems]   "

=Internationalization= [[Image:globalGame.jpg|frame|thumb|180px]] Internationalization has been viewed as a process of increasing involvement of enterprises in international markets.  Those entrepreneurs who are interested in the field of internationalization of business need to possess the ability to think globally and have an understanding of international cultures. By appreciating and understanding different beliefs, values, behaviors and business strategies of a variety of companies within other countries, entrepreneurs will be able to internationalize successfully. Entrepreneurs must also have an ongoing concern for innovation, maintaining a high level of quality, and continue to strive to provide the best business strategies and either products or services possible while adapting to different countries and cultures.  ==References== http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Internationalization

=International Economics=  International economics is a field of study that assesses the implications of international trade, international investment, and international borrowing and lending. There are two broad subfields within the discipline: international trade and international finance.  ==References==  http://catalog.flatworldknowledge.com/catalog/editions/48#

=International Marketing=  International marketing (IM) or global marketing refers to marketing carried out by companies overseas or across national borderlines. This strategy uses an extension of the techniques used in the home country of a firm. It refers to the firm-level marketing practices across the border including market identification and targeting, entry mode selection, marketing mix, and strategic decisions to compete in international markets. According to the American Marketing Association (AMA) \international marketing is the multinational process of planning and executing the conception, pricing, promotion and distribution of ideas, goods, and services to create exchanges that satisfy individual and organizational objectives.\"  ==References==  http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_marketing"

=Business Development=  A subset of the field of commerce, business development comprises a number of techniques and responsibilities which aim at: *1. Researching new types of business/products/services with an emphasis on identifying gaps (existing and/or expected) in the mitigation of needs of potential clients (existing and/or new ones). *2. Attracting new customers *3. Penetrating existing markets.   When you start a new business, you’ve spent a lot of time and effort on the business planning process. You must take and clarify the following questions:  *What will be the main profile (products/services) of the enterprise? *What the main goals and objectives?  *Which market segment will be targeted? *How should be your products/services positioning in the market? *Where are you/company now and how can be reached the aims? *Which tools are needed to use for the purposes?  ==References== http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Business_development

=Investment=  In finance, the purchase of a financial product or other item of value with an expectation of favorable future returns. In general terms, investment means the use money in the hope of making more money.  In business, the purchase by a producer of a physical good, such as durable equipment or inventory, in the hope of improving future business.   ==Reference== http://www.investorwords.com/2599/investment.html

=Operation and Logistics=  Every organization either manufactures a product, or provides a service, or both. \Operations\" refers to the part of the organization that actually produces the product or service, while \"logistics\" refers to the part of the organization that delivers the product or service to the customer.   ==References== http://www.sauder.ubc.ca/Faculty/Divisions/Operations_and_Logistics"

=Commercial law=  [[Image:CommercialLaw.JPG|frame|thumb|180px]]  Commercial law (also known as business law, which covers also corporate law) is the body of law that governs business and commercial transactions. Commercial law includes within its compass such titles as principal and agent, carriage by land and sea, merchant shipping, guarantee, marine, fire, life, and accident insurance, bills of exchange and partnership. It can also be understood to regulate corporate contracts, hiring practices, and the manufacture and sales of consumer goods.  ==References==  http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Commercial_law http://www.wiut.uz/en/courses/undergraduate/cl

=EU Internal Market=  [[Image:EUmarket.jpg|frame|thumb|180px]]   The rules governing the four freedoms of movement – for goods, services, people and capital – are not, by themselves, sufficient to achieve the objectives of the Single Market. These objectives can be fully achieved only if national and European policies create a favourable climate for business to grow across borders. Firms need to be confident that they can compete on a level playing field and that appropriate legal structures exist to allow all businesses, whatever their size, to operate effectively across the EU.  Harmonisation of the rules relating to company law and corporate governance, as well as to accounting and auditing, is a key element of this policy. This harmonisation aims at reducing red tape by helping companies to operate throughout the EU on the basis of a single set of rules and a unified management and reporting system.  ==References== http://ec.europa.eu/internal_market/top_layer/index_45_en.htm http://ec.europa.eu/internal_market/eu-go/index_en.htm

=Target Market=  A target market is a group of customers that the business has decided to aim its marketing efforts and ultimately its merchandise. A well-defined target market is the first element to a marketing strategy. The target market and the marketing mix variables of product, place(distribution), promotion  and price  are the four elements of a marketing mix strategy that determine the success of a product in the marketplace. Once these distinct customers have been defined, a marketing mix strategy of product, distribution, promotion and price can be built by the business to satisfy the target market.  ==References== INCO II. Internationalization Consulting is co-funded by the European Commission. http://www.inco2.at/index.php

=Business Planning=  Every planning process goes through a series of stages.  In essence the aim is to complete each of the following steps:  *Analyse the external environment *Analyse the internal environment *Define the business and mission *Set corporate objectives *Formulate strategies *Make tactical plans *Build in procedures for monitoring and controlling  ==References==  *http://managementhelp.org/businessplanning/index.htm *http://tutor2u.net/business/strategy/business-planning-process.html

=Market entry mode=  A market entry strategy is the planned method of delivering goods or services to a target market and distributing them there. When importing or exporting services, it refers to establishing and managing contracts in a foreign country. Entry Modes are specific forms or ways of entering a target country to achieve the strategic goals related to presence in that country. These can be trade related (Export), transfer related (Licensing, Franchising etc.), and foreign direct investment related (Acquisitions etc.).  ==References== INCO II. Internationalization Consulting is co-funded by the European Commission. http://www.inco2.at/index.php

=Venture capital Fund=  Venture capital (VC) is financial capital provided to early-stage, high-potential, high risk, growth startup companies. The venture capital fund makes money by owning equity in the companies it invests in, which usually have a novel technology or business model in high technology industries, such as biotechnology, IT, software, etc. The typical venture capital investment occurs after the seed funding round as growth funding round (also referred to as Series A round) in the interest of generating a return through an eventual realization event, such as an IPO or trade sale of the company. Venture capital is a subset of private equity. Therefore, all venture capital is private equity, but not all private equity is venture capital.  ==References== INCO II. Internationalization Consulting is co-funded by the European Commission. http://www.inco2.at/index.php

=Brownfield invsetment=  When a company or government entity purchases or leases existing production facilities to launch a new production activity. This is one strategy used in foreign-direct investment.  ==References== INCO II. Internationalization Consulting is co-funded by the European Commission. http://www.inco2.at/index.php

=Greenfield investment=  A form of foreign direct investment where a parent company starts a new venture in a foreign country by constructing new operational facilities from the ground up. In addition to building new facilities, most parent companies also create new long-term jobs in the foreign country by hiring new employees.    ==References== INCO II. Internationalization Consulting is co-funded by the European Commission. http://www.inco2.at/index.php

=Business Angles=  An angel investor or angel (also known as a business angel or informal investor) is an affluent individual who provides capital for a business start-up, usually in exchange for convertible debt or ownership equity. A small but increasing number of angel investors organize themselves into angel groups or angel networks to share research and pool their investment capital. Angel capital fills the gap in start-up financing between \friends and family\" (sometimes humorously given the acronym FFF, which stands for \"friends, family and fools\") who provide seed funding, and venture capital.  ==References== INCO II. Internationalization Consulting is co-funded by the European Commission. http://www.inco2.at/index.php "

=Foreign currency loan=  A foreign currency mortgage is a mortgage which is repayable in a currency other than the currency of the country in which the borrower is a resident. Foreign currency mortgages can be used to finance both personal mortgages and corporate mortgages. The interest rate charged on a Foreign currency mortgage is based on the interest rates applicable to the currency in which the mortgage is denominated and not the interest rates applicable to the borrower's own domestic currency. Borrowers have a liability to repay the mortgage in another currency and currency exchange rates constantly change. This means that if the borrower's domestic currency was to strengthen against the currency in which the mortgage is denominated, then it would cost the borrower less in domestic currency to fully repay the mortgage. Therefore, in effect, the borrower makes a capital saving.  ==References== INCO II. Internationalization Consulting is co-funded by the European Commission. http://www.inco2.at/index.php

=Trade=  Trade is the transfer of ownership of goods and services from one person or entity to another. Trade is sometimes loosely called commerce or financial transaction or barter. A network that allows trade is called a market.  ==International trade==  International trade is the exchange of capital, goods, and services across international borders or territories. In most countries, such trade represents a significant share of gross domestic product (GDP). While international trade has been present throughout much of history (see Silk Road, Amber Road), its economic, social, and political importance has been on the rise in recent centuries.  ===References=== *http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trade

=Export=  The term export is derived from the conceptual meaning as to ship the goods and services out of the port of a country. The seller of such goods and services is referred to as an \exporter\" who is based in the country of export whereas the overseas based buyer is referred to as an \"importer\". In International Trade, \"exports\" refers to selling goods and services produced in home country to other markets"

=Indirect exporting=  Indirect exports means selling goods to or through an independent domestic intermediary in their own home county. Then intermediaries export the products to customers foreign markets.

=Direct exporting=  Direct selling involves sales representatives, distributors, or retailers who are located outside the exporter's home country. Direct exports are goods and services that are sold to an independent party outside of the exporter’s home country. Mainly the companies are pushed by core competencies and improving their performance of value chain.

=Governing Law=  The body of law of a particular jurisdiction which governs the rights and responsibilities of parties in a given situation. Within limits parties may, by contract, choose which jurisdiction's law will govern matters related to contract formation, interpretation, and enforceability.  ==References== INCO II. Internationalization Consulting is co-funded by the European Commission. http://www.inco2.at/index.php

=International sales agreement=  A sales agreement is a \formal contract by which a seller agrees to sell and a buyer agrees to buy, under certain terms and conditions spelled out in writing in the document signed by both parties. International sales agreements may deal with different laws. Therefore it can come to misunderstandings and complications.  ==References== INCO II. Internationalization Consulting is co-funded by the European Commission. http://www.inco2.at/index.php "

=Management contract=  A management contract is an arrangement under which operational control of an enterprise is vested by contract in a separate enterprise which performs the necessary managerial functions in return for a fee. Management contracts involve not just selling a method of doing things (as with franchising or licensing) but involves actually doing them. A management contract can involve a wide range of functions, such as technical operation of a production facility, management of personnel, accounting, marketing services and training.  ==References== INCO II. Internationalization Consulting is co-funded by the European Commission. http://www.inco2.at/index.php

=Contract manufacturing=  Contract manufacturing is a process that establishes a working agreement between two companies. As part of the agreement, one company custom produces parts or other materials on behalf of their client. Benefits are:  *Labor cost advantages *Savings via taxation, lower energy costs, raw materials, and overheads *Lower political and economic risk *Quicker access to markets Caveats are: *Contract manufacturer may become a future competitor *Lower productivity standards *Backlash from the company’s home-market employees regarding HR and labor issues *Issues of quality and production standards  ==References== INCO II. Internationalization Consulting is co-funded by the European Commission. http://www.inco2.at/index.php

=Distribution agreement=  A distribution agreement  is one made between a manufacturer and a supplier to distribute and/or sell items manufactured. The supplier may make a distribution agreement  with separate stores selling the product that involves how goods will be merchandised or how much supplies will available to the store. A distribution agreement  may also include terms regarding advertising of a product.  ==References== INCO II. Internationalization Consulting is co-funded by the European Commission. http://www.inco2.at/index.php

'''Vállalatgazdaságtan'''
A vállalatgazdaságtan a vállalatok működésének elvi alapjaival és ezek gyakorlati következményeivel foglalkozik. Azokra a globális szemléleti és stratégiai alapokra támaszkodik, amelyekre a legjobb vállalati gyakorlatok épülnek. A vállalatgazdaságtan keretében tárgyalt főbb témakörök a következők: * a vállalati működésre ható társadalmi és gazdasági tényezők, beleértve többek között **a társadalmi felelősség kérdését, **a globalizációt **a tudás szerepének vizsgálatát. * a vállalati stratégia jellemzőit * a stratégia megvalósítására szolgáló folyamatokat, ahol **a stratégia szempontjából a vállalatnak kettős értékteremtő funkciója van: egyazon folyamatokban, integráltan kell megvalósítania az érték létrehozását a fogyasztó és a tulajdonos számára. *az értékteremtéshez vezető folyamatokat **marketinget, **az innovációt **az emberi erőforrás és a tudás menedzsmentjét, **a pénzügyet és a **termelés-szolgáltatás-logisztika folyamatait, ahol ***kiemelt szerepe van az értéklánc-szemléletnek, összekötve ezt a vállalatokon átívelő ellátási láncok kérdésköreivel.
